title: Take care. You're pregnant.
excerpt: Caring for ourselves has never been an option. The secret to a happy life is a healthy one. So, if taking care of yourself has always been so important, it is now crucial and beyond urgent. You are pregnant and you cannot take your pregnancy for granted. Your every action is going to be accounted for.
content:
Caring for ourselves has never been an option. The secret to a happy life is a healthy one. So, if taking care of yourself has always been so important, it is now crucial and beyond urgent. You are pregnant and you cannot take your pregnancy for granted. Your every action is going to be accounted for. Whatever you do, you're doing for your baby too. So while you are here, allow us to tell you what you must and must not do during your pregnancy.

Rest well. Meditate too.
You are bringing a baby into the world and your hormones are raging and playing ping pong. You are feeling ecstatic, angry, thrilled, sad, annoyed, loving, grumpy, and fussily hungry 24x7. It is not easy to ignore the myriad of emotions you are feeling simultaneously. In fact, it is almost impossible. So then, try and catch up on little naps throughout the day, it will calm you down. Or better still, meditate.

Eat right, not more.
The one thing that most pregnant women (and the experienced elders advising them) get wrong is that YOU DO NOT NEED TO EAT FOR TWO. You just need to eat for an adult and a teensy-meensy little one growing inside of you. Consume all or most of the needed minerals from their natural sources instead of banking on supplements. Ensure your eating the right foods to gift yourself and your baby the adequate portions of protein, calcium, iron, and all other vital minerals.

Stay active (but don't forget to rest).
While it is important that you rest yourself well, it is equally important that you treat yourself with a healthily active pregnancy. The keyword here is 'healthily active'. DO NOT hit the gym for a super cardio session, lift weights, or even go on marathons or sprinting sprees. But, keep moving in and around your home and workplace, indulge in light aerobics and yoga postures, do your chores yourself (cooking, partial cleaning, drying and folding clothes, etc.). If you choose to remain inactive, you'll become unhealthy as well.

Read!!
Everything (or at least most of what) you read is going to help you. So, read! Not just everything online, but also physical books. Read about what biology has got to say about pregnancy. Read about what mums have got to say about the rights and wrongs during pregnancy. Read about baby care. Read about a woman's postnatal care. Read about dada-baby relationship just as much as you read about mama-baby relationship. Read!!

Most of all, relax. Take a chill pill. You're going through a priceless phase. Cherish it.

title: Due date is almost here
excerpt: If you are going to be due for your delivery soon, use this as your checklist to prepare for the day you are going to be the happiest and the most tired (if that is even a word!!).It is only a matter of time.
content:
If you are going to be due for your delivery soon, use this as your checklist to prepare for the day you are going to be the happiest and the tiredest (if that is even a word!!).

Do everything we told you previously.

  • Rest well, maybe even more than you did in the past months of your pregnancy.
  • Meditate whenever you can.
  • Eat the right foods. No overeating (eat for 1.2, not for 2).
  • Continue doing simple chores (maybe simpler ones too).
    • Example
    • Don't dry clothes, but fold them
    • Move in and around your home (you're hopefully on your maternity leave and not going to work)
    • Peel and chop fruits and vegetables, even if you don't cook

But, you probably want to do these as well…

  • If this is your first baby, pamper your husband/partner as much as you can. You're going to not get the time or energy for it when your baby arrives.
  • If this is your second baby, pamper your baby #1 a lot and talk to him/her about how you will get busy when the new baby comes, but that you will always love him/her.
  • If this is your third baby, you must … Oh, you know the drill!
  • Prepare your hospital bag. Throw in your comfortable pyjamas or a loose maxi, nursing bras, toiletries, slip-ons, towels, gadgets and their chargers (you can skip this if you want), snacks you crave for, etc.
  • Prepare your baby bag. Onesies, sleepers, blankets, diapers, wet wipes, etc. Make your list.
  • Ensure that the crib is ready for your baby to slip right in.
  • Do not spare your freezer. Fill it with cooked and yet-to-be-cooked food. You're not going to find the time to cook or shop in the first few days of your little one coming along.
  • And after all this, relax. Take a chill pill. You're going through a priceless phase. Cherish it.

title: Say hello to your baby-boo
excerpt: Oh, the nightmares of labor are behind you. But, parenting has only just begun. Don't be anxious or restless.You'll witness yourself juggling a lot (hopefully, with your husband's help). We'll walk you through your new role in 5 easy steps....
content:
Oh, the nightmares of labour are behind you. But, parenting has only just begun. Don't be anxious or restless. We'll walk you through your new role in 5 easy steps.

1. You'll witness yourself juggling a lot (hopefully, with your husband's help). You'll have to feed, burp, clean your baby a lot, and sometimes all at once. And just when you think you are free to relax, your baby will need assistance to either sleep (giving you a tad bit time for yourself too) or wake up (for another cycle of feeding, burping, and pooping). Hard as it may sound, take time away from everything else and focus on giving your baby the best growth days of his/her life by doing it right and with utmost patience.

2. If you have been a multitasker and an overachiever all your life, it is time to lower that bar. When your baby comes along, the only multitasking you're going to be doing is feed, burp, and clean. While it may not seem like an accomplishment just yet, you'll soon know that it is going to be one of the greatest accomplishments of your life. After everything is done and dusted, you'll find yourself smiling at the littlest emotions you see on your baby's face and loving every moment his/her little fingers and toes touch you. So, it isn't so much about lowering your expectation (per say) as it is about expecting different things.

3. Don't be selfless (or stupid, or both). If someone offers to help by taking care of your baby or doing some of those things you are meant to do, do not even consider hesitating. JUST. SAY. YES.

4. Sleep and eat whenever you can. Your baby's sleeping. Perfect! Snuggle in. Your baby's being fed. Good. Demand that you should be too, right then. If you do not eat and sleep every chance you get, you are probably never going to.

5. Amidst all your juggling, multitasking, saying yes to help and no to everything else, and sleeping and eating (or the lack of it), do not ignore the priceless moments you get with your baby. Now that's pure ecstasy.

P.S. Remember to relax. Take a chill pill. You're going through a priceless phase. Cherish it.

Super foods for a breastfeeding mum:

  • Fish, especially Salmon - Like many other fatty fish, salmon too has lots of good fat called the DHA. DHA is important for your newborn's nervous system development.
  • Low-fat (or fat-free) dairy products - Yogurt, cheese, milk, ghee, butter, cottage cheese, are all great food choices when you breastfeed. They are great sources of calcium, vitamins B and D, and protein too.
  • Beans and Pulses - Beans, both fresh and dried, are great sources of iron and protein. It is the perfect food for a vegetarian who is not in the mood for a dairy food.
  • Oranges, Gooseberries, and other berries - Oranges, gooseberries and other citrus fruits are pumped with the much-needed vitamin C. Other berries, especially blueberries, are the best when you consider its yummy taste and antioxidant characteristics.
  • Eggs (egg yolks, as well) - Egg yolks are filled with vitamin D, which is just as essential as calcium for the strengthening of your and your baby's bones.
  • And of course, Water and other liquids - You know how important it is. And you know just why. Drink a lot of water and juices (fresh fruit and vegetable juice, if possible). Keep yourself super hydrated.

All said and done, relax. Take a chill pill. You're going through a priceless phase. Cherish it.

title: Fussy Eater. Look into Metabolic Disorders
excerpt: From mere lack of appetite to major developmental delays, metabolic disorders can have many repercussions in the health of your child. If you believe your child is suffering from one, then here is all you need to know and more.
content:
From mere lack of appetite to major developmental delays, metabolic disorders can have many repercussions in the health of your child. If you believe your child is suffering from one, then here is all you need to know and more.

What are metabolic disorders?

Metabolism is the way the body breaks down food into simpler substances. Sometimes owing to genetic conditions or defects, the body is unable to break down a substance that should be broken down, allowing a toxic residue to build up. In other cases, the body is unable to produce essential substance. This condition is broadly known as a metabolic disorder.

What are the common metabolic disorders?

There are over 1500 metabolic disorders known today, related to 20,000 genes. Every day a new gene is discovered that helps us in identifying metabolic disorders. Some of the common disorders are Galactosemia, Tyrosinemia, Methyl Malonic Acidaemia, Maple Syrup Urine Disease, Biotinidase deficiency, Hypothyroidism etc.

How can we detect them?

There are more than 200 specialised tests available in blood, urine, CSF, Bile etc. There are high specialised labs which can do biochemical analysis and identify any disorder and then confirm genetically, which is very important. Of course, the best way to detect them is right after the baby is born. This is done through Newborn Screening Tests.

Are treatments available?

For some of the disorders, treatments are now available, and this list is improving day by day. As of today, there are about 84 treatable disorders known. The treatment includes dietary changes, vitamins, some specific medicines, various enzyme replacement therapies, organ transplants and supporting care.

How can we prevent them?

Since they are genetic in origin, no one can prevent these from occurring. However, we can take care to prevent progression and damage. Early detection is key, and hence for some 55 disorders, newborn screening test – also called Expanded Newborn Screening Test – is used. More disorders are being included in the list every now and then. These are not routinely done in some parts of our country but in the western developed world, such programmes are national health programmes and universally available.

title: Pregnant, Here’s why your back is important.
excerpt: As your pregnancy advances, your body goes through a multitude of changes. These changes can be related to weight, hormones or even stress! This puts a lot of pressure on your spine and lower back.....
content:
As your pregnancy advances, your body goes through a multitude of changes. These changes can be related to weight, hormones or even stress! This puts a lot of pressure on your spine and lower back.


Here’s why you need to take care of your back:


  • Pregnancy Weight Gain - When you take care of your back and posture, the chance of you gaining a lot of weight is less. This will also ensure that complications will be minimal, and your labor will be considerably easier.
  • Proper Sleep - Sleep is very important during pregnancy, and taking care of your back ensures just that. You automatically sleep better and there are lesser instances of you waking up during the night.
  • Improves Self-Confidence - Pregnancy takes a toll on you physically as well as mentally. So, it’s important that you stay confident and show the confidence. The more confident you are, the more you glow!

So, how can you take care of your back? Here are a few things you can do:


  • Exercise Regularly: Exercising regularly can keep your back strong. Stretches, swimming, yoga and walking will keep your body strong and help you have a firm back.
  • Maintain a Good Posture: As your advance in pregnancy, your center of gravity shifts forward. This might result in you leaning back and walking, resulting in lower back pain. Maintain the right posture by standing up straight, holding your chest high and keeping your shoulders back.
  • Wear the right shoes: You must have heard this enough number of times, but it’s just that important. During pregnancy, avoid wearing high heels as well as flats. Wear low heels (0.5 to 1 inch) which have a good arch support.

Despite all this, if the back pain still persists, you should visit your doctor.

Here’s to having a happy and safe pregnancy!

title: Pregnancy and Coronavirus : What Pregnant Women Need to Know
excerpt: If you're pregnant, you may be unsure how coronavirus (COVID-19) could affect you, your baby and your pregnancy care. It's important to tell your doctor if you have symptoms of coronavirus.......
content:
If you're pregnant, you may be unsure how coronavirus (COVID-19) could affect you, your baby and your pregnancy care. It's important to tell your doctor if you have symptoms of coronavirus. You should also ask them for help with any other concerns as you usually would.

Pregnancy and Your Risk

There's no evidence that pregnant women are more likely to get seriously ill from coronavirus. But pregnant women have been included in the list of people at moderate risk (clinically vulnerable) as a precaution. This is because pregnant women can sometimes be more at risk from viruses like flu.

It's not clear if this happens with coronavirus. But because it's a new virus, it's safer to include pregnant women in the moderate-risk group. It may be possible for you to pass corona virus to your baby before they are born. But when this has happened, the babies have got better. There's no evidence corona virus causes miscarriage or affects how your baby develops in pregnancy.

What to do if you're Pregnant

If you're pregnant, it's important you:

  • Wash your hands regularly.

  • Stay at home as much as possible and follow the advice on social distancing, such as staying at least 2 metres (3 steps) away from other people.

  • Stay away from anyone who has symptoms of coronavirus.

You still need to go to all of your pregnancy (antenatal) scans and appointments unless you're told not to.

Appointments and Scans

You'll still have regular appointments and scans while you're pregnant. But there may be some changes.

You may find that:

  • Appointments are now online, by phone or by video call.

  • If you need to have a scan you may have to go on your own.

  • You may be asked to wear a mask or gown when you're in a hospital or opd.

  • Some appointments may be cancelled or rescheduled – if an appointment is cancelled, it will be rescheduled, or you'll be able to rebook it.

This is to help keep everyone safe and stop the spread of coronavirus.

title: Everything You Need To Know About Pneumonia : Signs, Treatment, Prevention
excerpt: Pneumonia is an infection of lungs. It is caused by microbes like bacteria and viruses and less commonly by others like fungi or parasites. Very rarely pneumonia can also be caused by the environmental pollutants/toxins......
content:
What is Pneumonia?

Pneumonia is an infection of lungs. It is caused by microbes like bacteria and viruses and less commonly by others like fungi or parasites. Very rarely pneumonia can also be caused by the environmental pollutants/toxins. 

Pneumonia often starts as a cold, sneezing, or runny nose. The infection can then track down to the lungs. The body’s immune response and the strength of the microbe can determine if the infection will progress to the lungs.  Pneumonia can occur in any age group from a newborn baby to an elderly person. 

The severity of the condition varies significantly. It can be very mild to even fatal. Predisposing factors like low immunity in the individual, malnutrition, diabetes, heart disease, smoking, asthma, chronic liver, or kidney diseases can increase the severity of the illness. A significant number of children die in India every year due to pneumonia. 

What are the signs or symptoms of Pneumonia?

Pneumonia presents with fever, productive cough, chest pain and difficulty, and/or fast breathing. When severe, the skin may turn a blue tinge, which denotes a low oxygen level in the blood. This is an ominous sign and medical help should be sought immediately. Other symptoms include tiredness or lethargy, difficulty in feeding, especially in children leading to dehydration and reduced level of alertness. 

Complications of pneumonia include the formation of pus within the lungs (lung abscess), collection of fluid/pus around the lung (Effusion/Empyema). 

How is Pneumonia treated?

Pneumonia is diagnosed with a careful history and clinical examination. Sometimes investigations like chest X-ray and blood tests may be required. Viral Pneumonia is given symptomatic treatment, whereas pneumonia caused by bacteria requires a course of antibiotics.

It is therefore essential that a doctor is consulted in order to initiate the right treatment. Complications such as empyema require a surgical procedure to clear the pus. This will also require a longer course of antibiotics. 

Can Pneumonia be prevented?

Pneumonia can be prevented with vaccines and the management of other health issues. These vaccines are included in the Universal Immunisation Schedule for Children in India. Yearly influenza vaccine protects us against the flu. Individuals with low immunity may require long term antibiotics for the prevention of pneumonia.  Improving general health by eating nutritional food, regular exercise, and cessation of smoking helps us in building our immunity. 

When unwell with a cold, coughing or sneezing in a tissue and washing hands after disposing of the tissue safely in a bin ensures we are limiting the spread of germs to others.

title: Importance of Breastfeeding Your Baby During COVID-19
excerpt: This statement very well sums up the benefits of breastfeeding. Mother Nature has been kind to bestow this wonderful gift of breast milk upon us. Hence, every effort must be taken to utilize it. The advantages of breastfeeding cannot be stressed enough......
imageTitle: Breastfeeding During COVID-19
content:
”Mother’s milk is the best milk”. 

This statement very well sums up the benefits of breastfeeding. Mother Nature has been kind to bestow this wonderful gift of breast milk upon us. Hence, every effort must be taken to utilize it. The advantages of breastfeeding cannot be stressed enough. The recommendations by WHO (World Health Organisation) are to exclusively breastfeed until 6 months, continued along with complimentary food until 2 years of age.

Why Breastfeeding is Important for Newborn Baby?

Breastfeeding not only provides nutrition that is perfect for the growth of babies but also offers immunity-boosting antibodies to fight against infections. Babies that are breastfed tend to have fewer incidences of allergies and asthma. The rate of obesity is also lower in babies who are breastfed. Breastfed babies have higher IQ compared to formula-fed babies.

Breastfeeding is not beneficial just for babies, it also helps mothers in several ways. It aids in building an emotional bond with the baby. Breastfeeding mothers lose weight quicker as a lot of calories are used up in the process of lactation. The risk of ovarian and breast cancer is also less in mothers who have breastfed. Across the world, breastfeeding has helped in reducing the infant mortality rate as well as improving maternal health.  

Breastfeeding Advice During the COVID-19

The current situation of COVID 19 poses challenges to new mothers and their babies. A lot of concerns have been raised about whether it is safe to breastfeed if mothers have either tested or suspected to be COVID positive. The primary concern being transmission of the infection to the newborn. 

However, at present, there has been no conclusive evidence to suggest that transmission of Coronavirus through breast milk is possible. Even WHO recommends that mothers who are either COVID positive or suspected to be COVID positive must be encouraged to breastfeed, as the benefits of breastfeeding far outweigh the risks of transmission of COVID 19. Babies rely upon the mother’s immunity, which is transmitted through breast milk, to fight off infections. Therefore, breastfeeding should be initiated soon after birth.

Safety precautions however must be taken by mothers with COVID, before they breastfeed. Mother should-

  1. Wash their hands thoroughly with soap and water for 30 secs

  2. Wash the breast area with soap and water

  3. Wear a face mask

If for any reason the mother is too unwell to directly breastfeed, she should be assisted to express her breast milk. The expressed milk can be fed to the baby by a nanny. In this way, we are ensuring that both mother and the baby are still benefited from breastfeeding albeit indirectly.  

Lactation consultants and nurses will be available in the hospital to help new mothers learn the skill of breastfeeding. If there are any other queries, take advice from the expert doctors.

title: Tips for Coping with a Newborn Baby During COVID-19
excerpt: Welcoming a new baby to the family is always a blissful moment. It can however be stressful too. The current situation of COVID 19 perhaps adds to the anxiety of new parents. The concern over COVID can overshadow the joyful experience of a new baby.......
imageTitle: Important Tips for Coping with a Newborn During COVID-19
content:
Welcoming a new baby to the family is always a blissful moment. It can however be stressful too. The current situation of COVID 19 perhaps adds to the anxiety of new parents. The concern over COVID can overshadow the joyful experience of a new baby. New parents are regularly surrounded by offers of multiple suggestions by their near and dear ones. It can often be confusing for parents to choose the advice they can follow.

Helpful Tips

It has been observed that Covid-19 is a respiratory disease that spreads through droplets. It is therefore pertinent to ensure the new baby, who is very vulnerable, does not needlessly get exposed. Restricting the visitors, maintaining social distance, ensuring hand hygiene, and avoiding unnecessary trips outside of the house is key to ensuring the safety of the new baby. Breastfeeding is also vital to provide the newborn with adequate nutrition as well as immunity-boosting antibodies to ward off infections.

Parents or nannies who handle the baby should regularly wash their hands before touching them. It is important to remember that these routines should be carried out not just during COVID, but even otherwise. If the baby becomes unwell, the paediatrician should be consulted immediately. Parents can utilize the facility of online consultation, should they feel anxious to take the baby out of the house. It is advisable that routine infant vaccinations are not delayed because of COVID.

Maternal health is paramount during the early postpartum period; a happy mother is a happy baby. As well as her physical health, attention must be also given to the new mother’s mental well-being. A new mother should have a good network of support that not only helps her with her physical needs but also lends an ear to listen out to her worries.

Final Thought

There is a lot of information available about COVID in the media. It becomes extremely difficult to filter out what is relevant to the general public and what is not. If you have any queries, please discuss it with your doctor. If not, simply enjoy your time with your bundle of joy. We will eventually see an end to this saga of COVID, however, till then, stay home and stay safe.

excerpt: Winters.! Well, we all love this season. But it gets tough when it is cold and, if you are a new mom, then you would want to protect your little one from the seasonal cold. Here are a few do's and don'ts that can help you to keep your little.......
imageTitle: Do’s and Don’ts, you need to follow to ensure the best care of your newborn during winters
content:
Winters.! Well, we all love this season. But it gets tough when it is cold and, if you are a new mom, then you would want to protect your little one from the seasonal cold. Here are a few do’s and don’ts that can help you to keep your little one safe and healthy from the elements this winter. 

 

Do’s

Use a humidifier in the room:

When it is too cold outside, we generally use a room heater to maintain the optimum room temperature. But if you use a heater, it makes the air dry, which may affect your baby's tender skin. Install a humidifier so that the moisture level is maintained.

Dress your baby comfortably:

Having your baby continuously wrapped up in a thick blanket could restrict your baby from moving freely and might be irritable. So always make sure that you choose comfortable yet warm clothes for your little one. Dress your baby in layers of clothes rather than a thick jacket or sweaters as you can put them on or take them off the baby, as needed.

Massage your little one:

Massage is necessary for the proper development and growth of a child. Massage the baby daily with good baby oil. It stimulates the blood flow in the body. And during winters, make sure you massage your baby in a warm room.

Moisturizer is a must during winter:

The infants' skin is very delicate and active as it is continuously developing. Hence it is more vulnerable to irritants, changes in temperature, and humidity. Moisturizing your baby's skin seals moisture in and helps maintain its natural protective barrier against external irritants. This ensures that the skin stays soft and healthy.

Exposure to Natural Sunlight:

Exposure to natural sunlight is beneficial for your newborn. Our body needs Vitamin D created in the body during exposure to the sun's UV rays. Expose the baby at least for a period of 15-20 min in the early morning or late afternoon sunlight. Vitamin D also aids in absorbing calcium that helps to strengthen bones and teeth. The immune system works efficiently and protects from diseases.

 

 

Don’ts

Don’t try lots of products:

The skin of your little one is sensitive, so moisturizers and baby creams are okay to use. However, if you use lots of products on the infant, it will only make the skin dry. Avoid using soaps and shampoo daily. These products will rob the moisture of your baby’s skin and make it dry.

Don’t miss the vaccinations:

Getting your child/baby vaccinated at the right time is highly important during winters, as your baby’s immune system will be low and be more susceptible to infections. In case, even if you miss it by chance, then get the next date confirmed and go for it without fail.

Avoid outdoor activities during winter:

As winter comes, it also comes with many health issues. As the infant will have less immunity, it will be easy to catch the infections. Hence avoid going out to public gatherings, functions, etc.

Don’t keep the diapers on for a long time:

Yeast grows on moisture and it can be quite painful as they form red blisters that can crack and bleed. Hence it is better to change the soiled diaper quickly. If your baby has diaper rashes, then it is better to change the diaper more frequently.

 

This winter keeps your baby safe and healthy by taking preventive measures beforehand. Make sure you maintain good hygiene at home and keep the house warm. But if you feel that your little one is not keeping well then, better consult your doctor.

title: Why is exercising important during pregnancy?
excerpt: Regular exercise is important for your general health. During pregnancy, it is beneficial for both mother and the baby to stay healthy. Regular exercise, yoga, workouts can help you in many ways during pregnancy and are extremely safe for your body.......
imageTitle: Why is exercising important during pregnancy?
content:
Regular exercise is important for your general health. During pregnancy, it is beneficial for both mother and the baby to stay healthy. Regular exercise, yoga, workouts can help you in many ways during pregnancy and are extremely safe for your body. It helps to improve your postures and reduce discomforts for later stages, resulting in a painless and smooth delivery.

Exercises to do during pregnancy are:

  1. Swimming and water workouts: In water, you weigh less than you do on land, so you’ll feel lighter and more agile. The weight of your growing infant is supported by the water and moving against it helps to keep your heart rate up and as the baby is flowing along with you, it’s gentle on loosening joints and ligaments, just be careful of slippery areas.

Benefits:

  • Keeps you cool

  • Relieve ankle and foot swelling

  • Reduce morning sickness

  • Ease sciatic pain and improves labor and experience 

 

  1. Walking: Walking is the best exercise that every pregnant woman can opt for and if you are new to exercise then it’s a great activity to start with. You can continue doing this exercise until your delivery date. It doesn't strain your joints and muscles. 

Benefits:

  • Helps you burn calories, and boosts your mood and energy levels

  • Eases back pain and other aches and helps you sleep better 

  • Decreases the risk of complications during pregnancy and delivery

  • Relieves constipation

 

  1. Yoga: This form of exercise and meditation helps you connect the mind and body through breath and specific body positions. Prenatal yoga mainly focuses on positions that are specifically designed for pregnant women’s bodies.

Benefits:

  • Lower’s your blood pressure 

  • Stabilize your moods 

  • Manage your weight

  • Reduce the risk of preterm labor and other complications

 

  1. Weight Lifting:  It’s safe to work out with weights as long as they’re not too heavy. It is a good way to build your muscle tone and make your bones strong. You can also switch to machines, but use light weights with multiple repetitions. Don’t forget to stretch once you're done.

Benefits:

  • Helps you to avoid aches and pains 

  • Strengthens your body for labor

  • Boosts metabolism

  • Improves posture

 

  1. Pilates: Pilates can help you modify or avoid poses that may be unsafe for pregnant women, like lying on your belly or flat on your back. You can focus on a pregnancy-appropriate pilates routine that mainly helps you in strengthening your core and lengthening your muscles, ease backaches and improve your flexibility.

Benefits:

  • Controls your breathing

  • Strengthens your pelvic floor

  • Strengthens your stomach and gluteal muscles

  • Strengthen legs

 

Things to be aware of during exercise :

  • Don’t exercise for more than 45 minutes a day.

  • Don’t hold your breath during any exercise or activities.

  • Avoid contact sports softball, football, basketball, and volleyball.

  • Be careful to keep your balance during exercises, such as cycling, horse riding, or skiing.

  • Don’t exercise at high altitudes.

  • Don’t over-exercise.

  • Stop exercising if you have any unusual symptoms, and contact your doctor immediately.

content:
One of the most common things during pregnancy every woman experiences is cravings for foods and goes crazy over them. But it's important to know which food is suitable and healthy for both mother and the baby. It is the moment where the mother has to be extra careful about what to eat and what not to eat and drink to stay healthy. There are certain food items that can be consumed minimally but some foods are a complete No No. 

Here is a list of food items that should be avoided during pregnancy:


Caffeine

Caffeine is a chemical found in many foods and drinks, including coffee, tea, and cola, etc, it is absorbed very quickly and passes easily into the placenta. Babies and their placentas don’t have the enzyme needed to metabolize caffeine.

Consuming large amounts of caffeine may increase the risk of miscarriage or low birth weight, so it's best to limit your caffeine intake. 


High Mercury Fish/Mercury in some types of fish

Mercury is a toxic element and is most commonly found in polluted water, Since it’s found in polluted seas, large marine fish can accumulate high amounts of mercury. 

If consumed in larger amounts can harm a developing baby's brain, it can be toxic to your nervous system, immune system, and kidneys, and also causes serious developmental problems in children, with adverse effects even in lower amounts.

Therefore, it’s suggested to avoid high mercury fish while pregnant and breastfeeding.


Undercooked or raw fish and meet

Consuming raw or undercooked fish can increase the risk of infections as your infant will be exposed  to mercury, bacteria, and other harmful parasites.

Some of these infections may only affect the mother, causing dehydration and weakness, but other infections may be passed on to your baby with serious, or even fatal, consequences. It leads to a stillbirth or severe neurological illnesses, including intellectual disability, blindness, and epilepsy.


Alcohol

Consuming any amount of alcohol is considered as not safe during pregnancy, as it causes fetal alcohol syndrome. Fetal alcohol syndrome occurs when the pregnant mother drinks excessive amounts of alcohol as it  passes through the placenta and into the baby's bloodstream.

Alcohol use during pregnancy can also lead to miscarriage and stillbirth, facial deformities, heart defects and intellectual disability, Hence it’s recommended to avoid it completely.


Unpasteurized milk, cheese, and fruit juice

Bacterias like Listeria, are found in unpasteurized milk and cheese, which can cross over into the placenta and lead to infections or blood poisoning for the baby, or even miscarriage, and also leads to fatal tuberculosis, death of the newborn baby,. Unpasteurized juice contains harmful bacteria from the raw fruits and vegetables used to make the juice. These bacteria can cause food poisoning (such as listeriosis and toxoplasmosis), which can be dangerous during pregnancy.


Raw sprouts

Raw sprouts can carry a risk of foodborne illness if they are contaminated. Unlike other fresh produce, the warm, moist conditions required to grow sprouts are ideal for the rapid rise of bacteria, including salmonella, listeria, and E. coli. And regardless of the number of times you wash them, traces of the bacterias are left behind. For this reason, even though you would like to consume raw sprouts, make sure you cook it well. 

It’s tough to avoid delicious food, but you can go for a healthy diet plan that is delicious too which will benefit you as well as your baby, and help you undergo a safe and healthy pregnancy.

imageTitle: Morning Sickness during pregnancy
content:
Morning sickness during pregnancy..! Not a good feeling at all. Morning sickness is usually the primary sign that a lady experiences during pregnancy. It begins around week 6 of pregnancy and subsides by the 3rd month. Occasionally, it can persist beyond 3 months. It usually happens within the first 3-4 months of pregnancy and is considered normal. Unlike its name, you can experience nausea at any time of day.

The most common signs and symptoms are nausea and vomiting, which are often triggered by certain odors, spicy foods, heat, excess salivation, or no triggers at all.

A very common complaint every pregnant woman has, so how to deal with it? Below listed are a number of the ways that can help you to alleviate morning sickness;

Ditch work and take some rest:

Going through one of those mornings when the thought of dragging yourself out of bed for work is tough? Take a leave, give yourself a break. Women who work night shifts can opt to wear a sleep mask. As time passes, it’s necessary for the mother and the baby in the womb to get some good sleep. Napping may help too, but not straight after a meal, as it can increase nausea. Go to bed early and wake up early, do not use sleeping pills unless prescribed by a doctor.

Eat foods that work best for you:

Women usually tend to have food cravings but some food items may upset your tummy. Many women find it easier to keep down certain types of foods like fatty and spicy foods as they increase the chance of triggering the release of stomach acid, but it's not the same for every woman, if you find that they work for you then go ahead and have them. List of foods to avoid during pregnancy.

Eat little & more frequently:

An empty stomach can make nausea even worse. To avoid this, eat smaller, more frequent meals in place of 3 large meals a day. Eating too much can also upset your stomach. Eat-in small sizes so that there is something in your tummy. When your stomach is empty, the stomach acids have nothing to feed on except for the stomach lining. This increases the feeling of nausea. Keeping your stomach a little bit full all the time is the best way to beat nausea.

Stay Hydrated:

It’s important to intake more fluids, as drinking enough fluids can help you feel well during pregnancy. If you're being sick/ have excess morning sickness that may be due to dehydration as there is more loss of water content than you intake. Always try to keep a glass or bottle of water nearby and take regular sips. Being hydrated also helps you to overcome some of the problems like constipation and tiredness. Some of the healthy fluids to intake are; fruit teas, fruit juices, ginger and peppermint teas, and so on.

Stay active: Physically & Mentally:

Being physically active has been found to enhance the symptoms in women who experience nausea during pregnancy. Keeping yourself busy can help take your mind off the feelings of nausea. Reading a book, solving puzzles, watching television, playing cards, or a little walk around the block will help you stay preoccupied.

Wear comfortable clothes:

Women who experience nausea during pregnancy have fewer symptoms only when they wear wise, loose, and lightweight comfy clothes. Avoid restrictive and tight clothing as they worsen the symptoms of nausea.

Morning Sickness is considered to be common and normal during pregnancy. The above tips may help you find relief and feel better. But some women can experience severe forms of morning sickness, this can be due to severe nausea and vomiting leading to dehydration. In such cases, it’s recommended to consult your doctor.

imageTitle: 5 important stages of Child Growth and Development
content:
As children grow every day, they evolve rapidly. Their changes are physical, emotional, intellectual, social, and psychological. Their cognition improves with age. These changes affect the way children think and learn.

5 important stages of Child Growth and Development:- 

Every child develops at their own individual pace. Here are some important stages of Child Growth and Development:

Birth (Baby birth - 2 years old):

Each child is unique. After birth, raising a baby especially for the first time, as a new parent is both exciting and challenging, you’ll experience a deep bond with your baby, along with the baby being entirely dependent on you for nutrition, warmth, and comfort. 

Your baby will begin to: 

  • Develop a social smile at the age of 6 weeks.
  • Once your baby is about 2-4 months, he/she will be able to recognize faces and start making noises such as cooing.
  • Will start raising head while being laid on its tummy, i.e there will be the development of motor skills.
  • Admire new colors and they start using their hands and mouth to explore the world around them.
  • Will start responding to touches, mouth-opening, head-turning, and grasping for objects.
  • They become wary of strangers and prefer being with their loved ones.

 

Toddler:

Once the baby starts to take the first step on his/her own, it indicates a new phase in development. Around this stage, children start to roam around much, as it is a time for active exploration of their environment. Development of language takes place significantly, leading him/her to learn the names of objects of interest, the ability to ask for things, and use words like Yes or No. Parents start preparing their children for school, where rapid physical and intellectual development takes place. Parents are considered to be their first teachers as they start learning first at home.

Your toddler will begin to:

  • Walk around, unstoppable.
  • Enjoy activities like coloring, block building, etc.
  • Development of language skills.

 

Preschoolers:

Passing toddlerhood and stepping into a new stage of life. In preschoolers, they find themselves in a new world of exploration and formal learning. Children usually start going to kindergarten during this stage that is around the age of 5-6. During this period of development, preschoolers start learning numbers, letters, and simple math. They also start improving their gross motor and fine motor skills, which gets them curious about art, crafts, and all other sorts of ride-on toys (wagons, scooters, bikes, etc.).

Your preschooler will begin to:

  • Engage in conversation.
  • Will begin reading and enjoy books.
  • He/She will start running around and engaging in outdoor exercise.

 

School-Age:

Children will start trying new activities like athletic events.  While toddlers and preschoolers need constant supervision, school-age children become ready to be more independent. Parents ought to impart a moral code that the child gradually internalizes. During this stage children struggle with the daily essential tasks, parents must praise and encourage them, but they must also allow their kids sometimes to experience the natural consequences for their behavior or provide logical consequences to help them learn something new from the mistakes.

  • Develop an interest in sports or other activities that capture their interest.
  • Form friendships and engage in social development.
  • Exhibit an inclination to be independent.

Parenting Teenagers:

 Without doubt parenting teenagers is challenging for both parents and children.  Secondary/Middle School is often remembered as fraught with scary body changes, bullying by kids, and an urge for independence, which leads to passive-aggressive behavior. Being in high school is a time to begin defining one’s self. Development of skill is accelerated to prepare for college programs or job training programs. Teenager’s pressure will be at its max, as in today’s teen society there are more tempting sidetracks than ever. During adolescence, kids need their parents more than ever and anyone else. 

We hope this is being helpful for parents who can understand what is happening in their child’s mind and body during each period and can provide the necessary support, and encouragement to enable a child to progress through each stage as smoothly and successfully as possible based on each child’s unique set of traits and interests. imageTitle: 5 things you need to know about your newborn baby
content:
Having a baby is a life changing experience! As a soon to be mom, you may start wondering about how your newborn will look like, how to take care of your baby but what will it really be like after you bring your little one home?

To help you prepare yourself, here are 5 things you need to know about those first three months with the newborn.

1. Newborn baby’s first poo will surprise you: Being a parent for the first time, you will be surprised with the amount of waste matter your newborn can create. During the first few weeks, your newborn will poop and spit alot, you will have to change diapers/nappies for every time you feed them. For cleaning up, use a ball of cotton dipped in water, and apply petroleum jelly to avoid rashes.

2. Your Newborn’s tummy is never full: Your newborn’s tummy at birth is small. Your newborn has a tummy of the size of a cherry. It can hold 5-10ml of milk at a time. This gradually increases to hold 30ml of milk by the time they are a couple of weeks old. New mothers also lactate similar amounts of milk to suit the needs of the baby.

3. Newborns don’t have a sleep routine: Newborn babies sleep a lot, as well as wake up too many times. They don’t follow any fixed routine to sleep, and as the time passes they start to adjust to a sleep pattern. Newborns will not be able to close their eyes fully as they sleep, making you wonder whether the baby is asleep or not. They may sleep the entire day and stay awake the whole night or vice versa. 

4. Your newborn will cry a lot: The only way they can communicate with you is by crying. At first, all these things seem to be overwhelming but after a while, you will be able to figure out how to respond and the reason when your baby starts crying. Usually babies  cry when they are hungry, feeling uncomfortable, some sort of irritation, or diaper change. 

5. Newborn’s skin peels off: Do not get worried when you see your newborn’s skin peeling off as it is a natural consequence after birth. After being 9 months in the womb covered by amniotic fluid, your little one’s skin does not exfoliate as adults’ skin does and is too sensitive to dry air so the skin might start to peel off. Use a baby moisturizer to keep your little one’s skin soft.

Every new parent may need some help, there are numerous things you will get to know about your newborn as they grow and develop. So instead of getting worried and anxious, enjoy your new motherhood/ parenthood period. You may also read the 5 important stages of child growth and development.

imageTitle: Effects of hypothyroidism on baby during pregnancy
content:
Hypothyroidism is nothing but is a condition where the thyroid gland is Underactive . In hypothyroidism the body produces inadequate thyroxine hormone particularly common in women of childbearing age. Thyroxine is an important hormone which is essential for normal functioning of every vital organ in the body

 

Symptoms of hypothyroidism:

Symptoms may be mild and may start slowly. The most common symptoms are as follows:

  • Tiredness, Excessive sleep

  • Hoarse voice, and swelling of face

  • Weight gain, and constipation

  • Dry skin and loss of hair

  • Brittle nails

  • Carpal tunnel syndrome 

  • Slow heart rate, leading to shortness of breath

  • Muscle cramps, weakness, joint pain

If you have any/some of the above symptoms visit your gynecologist and get started with the treatment and medications.

 

Effect of Hypothyroidism on the baby in the womb:

During pregnancy, the unborn baby totally relies on the mother for thyroid hormones. These hormones are vital for the development and growth of the brain of the baby. It is always best to ensure and get thyroid disorder checked before conceiving, as the disorder may leave long-lasting effects on the baby. It is always best to consult with your physician to ensure your thyroid status and take the recommended thyroid medication consistently throughout your pregnancy. However, if you are not aware of it and find yourself pregnant, then you should contact your physician immediately to arrange for increased testing of your thyroid functions and a potential change in your medication.

Untreated or poorly controlled hypothyroidism can lead to:

  • Miscarriage

  • Premature birth

  • Pre-eclampsia

  • Stillbirth

 

How is the Thyroid function tested?

Thyroid tests must be taken approximately every 4 weeks during the initial weeks of pregnancy to ensure that the lady has no hypothyroidism. Post-delivery, the woman may go back to her usual pre-pregnancy dose of levothyroxine. It is important to recognize that prenatal vitamins contain iron and calcium that can impair the absorption of thyroid hormone from the gastrointestinal tract. Consequently, levothyroxine and prenatal vitamins shouldn't be taken at the same time, there should be a break of a minimum of 4 hours and thyroxine should be taken first thing in the morning on an empty stomach, preferably at the same time every day. You will have blood tests measuring thyroid hormone (thyroxine, or T4) and serum TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) levels. If TSH levels are above normal and T4 levels are below normal then that means you have hypothyroidism. Routine screening for hypothyroidism is not advised during pregnancy.  A pregnant woman with symptoms of hypothyroidism, a family history of the condition, or other system conditions should be tested.

Doctors can also recommend testing in women over the age of 60, even though they do not have symptoms. If you have one or more of the symptoms of hypothyroidism, or if anyone in your family had thyroid disease, consult the best endocrinologist. However, Women having hyperthyroidism can have a healthy pregnancy by getting early prenatal care and working with healthcare providers in the management of the disease.

content:
Pregnancy is undoubtedly a blissful event in every woman’s life.  It is also a new experience and hence thrilling at the same time. It is one of the major turning points in any couple's life. The couple's stepping into parenthood for the very first time starts brimming with questions, answers to many of which are provided by their relatives, family members, or friends. But should you trust those answers?  Too often, suggestions and advice are superstitions that hold no truth that you need to stop believing.


Some of the most common pregnancy misconceptions that you need to stop believing in:

MYTH: Pregnant women need to eat for two

A new life is growing inside you.  Well, in reality, you need to consume an extra 300 to 350 calories with your daily recommended diet of 2000 calories. Rather than focusing on the number of calories you intake, try to focus on the quality of food you choose to eat and learn about the food you need to avoid during pregnancy. Further, maintain a proper pregnancy diet and make sure that you are gaining a healthy amount of weight throughout your pregnancy. Every person is different, and only you know what is right for you. For more information about calorie intake during pregnancy, please consult the best gynecologist. 

MYTH: It’s not safe to bath during pregnancy

Well, to maintain good personal hygiene we have to bathe regularly. Never let the core body temperature rise above 102.2 degrees Fahrenheit as it may lead to prenatal issues. So be mindful of water temperature before you bathe. You can wash your hair with boiled ginger water to prevent or reduce the chances of skin infections. It can also help you relieve body aches and pains. 

MYTH: Don’t exercise while you are pregnant 

We all know that workouts during pregnancy are required to maintain good health for both the mother and the baby. But keep in mind certain things that you need to be aware of while doing exercise. A pregnant woman can exercise for 20-30 minutes daily. Exercises like walking, yoga, swimming or water sports, or Pilates can help you with backaches, sleep, blood circulation, and constipation. Avoid risky exercises in which you may fall, like skiing, horseback riding, and bouldering. You should stop exercising if you feel any unusual symptoms and consult the doctor immediately. Know why you should exercise during pregnancy.

MYTH: Heartburn means your baby will have loads of hair

Heartburn is usual during the pregnancy period due to the hormones that cause the lower esophageal sphincter at your stomach to stay relaxed and open up. That is when a pregnant woman experiences heartburn. 2006 study shows that mothers who had heartburn predominantly gave birth to babies with average to above-average hair growth, but connecting these two things is a stretch.

There are tons of pregnancy myths or misconceptions that people say and believe. Moms-to-be, don’t fall for these kinds of myths as they can cause harm to you or your baby.

imageTitle: Newborn Sleep Patterns; Parenting tips!
content:
Every one of us has a sleep pattern, so do babies.! Once the baby is out after spending nine months in the mother's womb, they develop their sleep cycles, which is natural to the babies, though it's strange for the parents. They tend to sleep all day and night, waking up only when they are hungry. A Baby’s sleep patterns may seem random at first but they evolve as they grow. Babies don’t know how to put themselves to sleep or how to wake up as they aren’t born knowing all these things.


If your newborn sleeps all day and wakes up all night long or vice versa, or if they exhibit other common infant sleep patterns like waking up frequently during the night, restless sleeping, or waking up early in the morning, it’s all completely normal.

Here’s what parents need to know about newborn’s sleep patterns:

● Trouble falling asleep:

If your baby is having trouble falling asleep during bedtime, then that might be because the baby doesn’t like its crib, maybe the crib is smaller in size for the baby to roll over in sleep, or isn't comfortable. One more reason can also be that the baby feels more comfortable being in the mother's embrace. If that’s the case, try to make the baby feel comfortable by putting it down to sleep.

● Waking up too often at night:

Babies tend to sleep all day/night and wake up only when they are hungry, while babies with their tummy full tend to wake up every three to four hours. If you feel too exhausted to keep getting up as and when the baby wakes up, you can seek help from your family so that you can rest for some time.


● Fussiness while sleeping:

It's very hard to predict whether your newborn is in deep sleep or not. Sometimes your baby might not be comfortable even though everything is perfect. When there’s too much brightness in the room or some activity/disturbance around the baby, they might feel uncomfortable. The only solution is to make an environment as comfortable as possible for the baby. You can use blackout shades, white noise machines to encourage dozing off.

● Refusing to sleep:

Newborns refuse to sleep when they are overtired, it’s not that they don't want to sleep, but it’s hard for your baby to go to sleep. Every woman during the initial period of their pregnancy starts to develop food cravings. This is where you have to take a little extra care about what to eat and what not to eat. You have to maintain a healthy diet. Doctors recommend the intake of 400 micrograms (mcg) of folic acid before and during pregnancy to prevent birth defects. Folic acid is nothing but a synthetic form of vitamin B9 also called folate. The role of folate is to produce red blood cells and develop the baby's brain and spinal cord. The best source of folic acid is green vegetables, citrus fruits, and fortified cereals.

When & How much should you start taking folic acid?

It is required to have folate in your diet system during the early stages of pregnancy when the baby's brain and spinal cord are developing. Usually, birth defects occur within the first 3-4 weeks of pregnancy, so intake of folic acid capsules can reduce the chance of birth defects and premature birth too. Study shows that women who included folic acid in their diet for at least a year before conceiving had cut their chances of delivering early by 50% or more.

Here's how much folic acid is recommended each day in terms of each stage of pregnancy:

Stage of Pregnancy

Dosage of Folic Acid

While trying to conceive

400 mcg

First 3 months of your pregnancy

400 mcg

4 to 9 months of pregnancy

600 mcg

During breastfeeding

500 mcg

 

Benefits of folic acid

Taking folic acid supplements is beneficial for women and the baby;

  • Protects your baby from neural tube defects like Spina bifida and Anencephaly.

  • Decrease the chances of premature birth and miscarriage.

  • Prevents certain types of cancer like lung, breast, pancreas, and gut.

  • Protects the baby from Cleft lip and palate, and poor growth in the womb.

  • Reduces the risk of heart disease, Alzheimer’s disease, Stroke.

  • Controls fertility in both men and women. 

Some Folic Acid Rich Foods

In case if you are hesitant about consuming folic acid supplements, then you can gain it naturally from certain foods that are rich in folic acid:

  • Fortified cereals

  • Leafy green vegetables

  • Asparagus

  • Avocado

  • Fruits like papaya, bananas

  • Okra

  • Legumes like beans, lentils, peas

  • Beets

  • Citrus fruits like oranges, lemon, grapefruit, lime

  • Egg

  • Brussels sprouts

Also, learn about foods to avoid during pregnancy! 

Side-Effects Of Folic Acid While Pregnant

Folic acid consumed naturally through food items is considered to be safe. But intake of a larger dosage than the prescribed amount could be unsafe, as anything in excess is harmful. The consumption of 300-400 mcg of folic acid during pregnancy is advisable.

Abdominal pain…!
Some abdominal pain during pregnancy is normal while some pain may be sharp, dull, or achy. Abdominal pain during pregnancy is normal. During pregnancy, your organs are constantly adjusting to the developments in the uterus that is expanding. This development may cause aches and pains. It is difficult to determine if your pain is normal or due to any abnormality.


Here are some of the common causes of abdominal pain during pregnancy, which pose no threat to you and your baby:


  • Round Ligament Pain
  • Gas and Constipation
  • Braxton Hicks Contractions
  • Common Discomforts

However, if you experience severe abdominal pain then it is wise to consult the gynaecologist immediately as it may be due to some abnormality, a few of which are listed below;


  1. Urinary Tract Infection:


    An infection in any part of your urinary systems like kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra, are easily treated during pregnancy, but if you neglect, it may lead to complications. Symptoms of having UTI are pain, discomfort, or burning sensation when urinating. The infection also produces lower abdominal pain. You notice pain in your lower back, sides of the body, under the rib cage, or above your pelvic bone accompanied by fever, nausea, sweats, or chills. Seek medical attention as soon as possible.


  2. Miscarriage:


    The most common form of pregnancy loss is a miscarriage, about 15 to 20 percent of pregnancies end in miscarriage. It is also known as “spontaneous abortion”. Miscarriage usually occurs in the first 13 weeks of pregnancy.
    Symptoms of a miscarriage:


    • You will experience mild to severe back pain.
    • True contractions happen every 5-20 minutes.
    • Brown/Red color bleeding with or without cramps.
    • Tissue or clot-like material passing from the vagina.

  3. Ectopic Pregnancy:


    This occurs in 1 out of 50 pregnant women when a fertilized egg gets implanted anywhere other than the uterus. Most often, in an extrauterine location like the fallopian tube, the egg is implanted. However, an ectopic pregnancy cannot continue to term and could be a medical emergency.

            Women with ectopic pregnancies may experience intense pain and bleeding during the 6th and 10th weeks of pregnancy. Women who have had an ectopic pregnancy in the past or have had endometriosis, a tubal ligation, or an intrauterine device (IUD) during the time of conception are at increased risk of ectopic pregnancies.



  4. Placental abruption:


    This is a life-threatening condition where the placenta separates from your uterus before the baby is born. Symptoms of placental abruption:


    • You will experience constant pain that causes your stomach to stay hard for an extended period without relief.
    • True contractions happen every 5-20 minutes.
    • Blood fluid or premature breakage of water.
    • Back pain / fluid discharge that may contain traces of blood.


  5. HELLP Syndrome:


    A condition in pregnancy characterized by high blood pressure and protein in the urine after 20 weeks of gestation. You will experience upper abdominal pain, accompanied by other symptoms used to diagnose preeclampsia.


    Know how to ease abdominal pain during pregnancy:


    Wondering what could be done to help ease abdominal discomfort during pregnancy! The treatment depends on what's causing the pain, but these tips might help you to avoid pain:


    • Eat small, frequent meals
    • Exercise regularly
    • Include fiber-rich foods
    • Drink plenty of water
    • Empty your bladder often
    • Rest frequently

        During pregnancy, your blood volume increases up to 50 percent as blood supplies oxygen and essential nutrients to your baby through the placenta and carries carbon dioxide out. The most common cause of infertility is ovaries not being able to produce an egg. This issue becomes predominant above a certain age. The other causes could be poor functioning of fallopian tubes, wherein the fallopian tube might be damaged or scarred by disease endometriosis. Problems with the uterus can also cause infertility. In males, low sperm count/poor sperm quality can also be the reason for infertility. Today, with the help of technology, infertility is treatable.

Infertility is the inability to conceive or to carry the pregnancy to full term. With various fertility treatments, there is a better chance of being able to conceive.


Fertility medicine:


The first step in treating infertility is through aiding the process through fertility medicine. Right fertility medicine increases the chance of conceiving by promoting ovulation. Some fertility drugs work by stimulating hormones in the brain that stimulate the egg to develop and release from the ovary, while other fertility drugs work by stimulating the ovaries to produce eggs. Advantage of fertility drugs is that it also helps improve and balance female hormonal levels.


Intrauterine Insemination (IUI):


It is a popular reproductive technique where sperm is deposited directly into the uterus through a woman's cervix. Artificial insemination and IUI may benefit those with male factor infertility, unexplained infertility, or cervical mucus problems. IUI also helps single women and gay couples get pregnant and have children using donor sperm.


In vitro fertilization (IVF):


It is a method of assisted reproduction involving surgical removal of the egg from the ovary and combining it with the semen prepared in the culture dish where fertilization takes place. Post fertilization, the embryo is transferred to the woman's uterus.


Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI):


This technique is helpful for male infertility problems, such as low sperm count, poor sperm quality, or sperm that cannot fertilize the egg. With this technique, a man's sperm is injected directly into the egg for IVF.


Egg-freezing:


This technique involves stimulating the ovary with hormones to produce multiple eggs, retrieving the eggs from the ovary, and storing them in the laboratory, where they are refrigerated to a subzero temperature. Frozen eggs are stored at -196 degrees temperatures so that they do not deteriorate over time. Eggs can then be retrieved and used for in-vitro fertilization (IVF) or ICSI.


Donor sperm:


Pregnancy through donor sperm is achieved by placing the donor sperm into a woman's vagina, cervix, or uterine cavity. Donor sperm helps overcome male infertility when a man has low sperm count or does not have sperm, or poor sperm quality.


Donor eggs:


Donor eggs from volunteers are fertilized externally using a partner's sperm or donor sperm. The fertilized embryo is then placed into the woman's womb for implantation and pregnancy. Women may choose to use donor eggs if ovarian reserve or premature ops are low. Some women use donor eggs to reduce the risk of inherited disease.

  • Anticipate Your Baby’s Desires: Instead of waiting to feed until your baby cries, you can anticipate when your baby feels hungry by observing a few signs like turning or raising their head repeatedly, sticking out their tongue, or sucking on whatever is in their hand. If you happen to see your baby making these moves, offer your breast right away.

  • You are going to spend a long time holding your baby to your breast while feeding. You have to do this in a supported sitting position to feel comfortable. But if you are sitting without a backrest for a long time while breastfeeding, it can lead to significant back, shoulder, and neck pain. You can use one of two positions for comfortable breastfeeding, lie on your side with your baby facing you or sit in a reclined position with your baby in your arms.

  • Help Your Baby Find The Right Position: Your baby will probably find a comfortable position by itself. You can observe this position so that you can make it easier to get into quickly. Few guidelines to find the best position that works for both you and your baby.

    • They should not have to turn their heads too much.

    • Their head should be slightly tilted backward.

    • If at all possible, they should latch the entire areola, not just the nipples.

    • Their chins should be against your breast so that their nose is clear.

  • Leaking Is Natural: During the first few weeks of breastfeeding, it is common for the milk to leak from your breast. Don't be alarmed, it is totally normal. This can happen when you hear another baby cry, or when your baby has not been nursed for several hours. This leak will eventually decrease or disappear completely as your baby starts nursing. In the meantime, you can put a nursing pad on your bra to absorb the leaks.

  • Avoid Engorgement: When you produce more milk than your baby consumes, you will experience painful swelling and hardening of your breasts. It is breast engorgement. This swelling can make it more difficult for your baby to feed, so the best way to avoid this painful condition is to nurse your baby as often as possible. Still, if engorgement persists, you can hand-express breast milk by gently massaging the areola between your fingers.

But what can cause low birth weight.! Let’s see some reasons that result in babies being born with low birth weight:


Cause of Low Birth Weight: pregnancy:


Gestational age:


        The period from conception to childbirth is known as gestation. During this period, the baby grows and develops in the womb. Gestational age determines the pregnancy duration as a combination of weeks and days.


       It is important to know the day you conceived. Even if you don't remember, your gynecologist will determine by analysing the menstrual cycle. The age of gestation helps to estimate the probable date, guide obstetric care and testing, and evaluate the health of the baby. It also serves as a guide to determine if the baby is growing as expected and when the prenatal tests have to be conducted. Babies born smaller or larger than expected at their gestational age need to be monitored more closely.



Premature Birth:


        Most of the time, low birth weight is caused when a baby is born too early than the gestational period. A premature baby born before 37 weeks spends less time in the womb to grow and gain weight. Studies show that low birth weight may increase the risk of non-communicable diseases, such as diabetes and cardiovascular problems, in the future.


Fetal growth restriction:


        A condition where the fetus cannot attain the genetically determined size. Babies born with fetal growth restriction are estimated to weigh less than the 10th percentile. Fetal growth restriction can occur either in the beginning of the pregnancy weeks or later in the pregnancy period and with fetal growth restrictions, the baby does not grow well; it affects the size of the baby and growth of organs, tissues, and cells, causing many health problems.


Placental Causes for IUGR:


       IUGR (Intrauterine Growth Restriction) can result from suboptimal supply of nutrition to the fetus. It usually happens when there is a problem with placenta, the tissue that supplies nutrients and oxygen to the baby or when there is problem with the flow of blood in the umbilical cord that connects the baby with the placenta resulting in premature birth or stillbirth.


       Intrauterine Growth Restriction can be caused if the pregnant woman has an infection, has a medical condition like anemia, clotting problems, high blood pressure, thyroid disease and other chronic diseases.


Infections


       Unknown infections or infections such as chickenpox, toxoplasmosis, and sexually transmitted infections (STDs) can lead to low birth weight.



Other factors that contribute to lower birth weight are as follows:


Chronic health conditions:


       Chronic health conditions like diabetes, kidney problems, lung problems, or heart problems last for a long time and they recur from time to time. As time passes, it can get worse and you will need extended treatment.


Regular medications:


       A soon-to-be mom must contact a health professional if they are on regular medications to treat health problems such as persistent cough, epilepsy, heart problems, or high blood pressure (hypertension).

Whether it is your first-, second- or third-time giving birth to a baby, every time will feel different from your pre-pregnancy self to post-pregnancy self. After all, you just gave birth to a human being…!


You will be advised to just rest and take care of yourself, but if you are keen to get moving, get back to work, follow a routine, and start exercise and workouts. If you have been through a healthy pregnancy and delivery, you can start working when you feel ready. If you had a cesarean delivery or diastasis recti or severe vaginal tears, you need to consult your doctor to determine when it is safe to exercise again. You may have to wait a few weeks to get back into the exercise program. Until then, rest, recover and relax.


Exercise that you can do post-delivery are as follows:


Upper Body Exercise:


  • Single- Arm Rows: This exercise helps you to strengthen your upper body. And it can be done using a dumbbell or resistance band. First, keep your shoulders square if you are using a cable/band stand tall, but if you are holding a dumbbell, (make sure it's 0.5 - 2kg). Engage your core and pull back, holding on to the weight, and make sure your elbow is at a 90-degree angle. Repeat these steps to strengthen your upper back.

  • Wall Plank: It’s a great exercise for those women who have gone through a c-section surgery. Keep your feet planted about 2 feet from the wall. Relax your forearms against the wall and stand in a plank position. Slowly move your body outwards by pulling your shoulder back, and place the sideboard on the wall, and that's it.

  • Swiss ball bird dog holds: Since back pain is common post delivery, this exercise can help you to relieve back pain. It also helps with stability and posture. Stability or an exercise ball is required to perform this exercise. Lay down on top of the ball and make sure that your torso covers the ball. Your body will be in a straight line, with your palms on the floor and toes touching the ground. Now, by looking down at the floor, lift the left foot and reach your right arm at the same time. Hold for 1 to 2 seconds and repeat the same.

Core Exercises:


  • Pelvic Floor Exercises (Kegels): There is a good chance that your body already knows how to make Kegel. Doing this exercise helps strengthen the pelvic floor muscles. Tighten your pelvic floor muscles, hold for 10 seconds and repeat.

  • Diaphragmatic breathing: This exercise can be performed within the first few days of delivery. It helps to improve core stability and slows down your breathing rate. Lie down on a yoga mat, relax your body, release the tension from your toes to the head top, put one hand on your chest and another on your stomach, take a deep breath in from your nose. It will expand your stomach, while your chest should remain relatively still. After breathing in for 2 to 3 seconds, breathe out slowly.

  • Dead Bugs: Start in the head position with your legs and arms stretched straight up into the air. Inhale and lower your left arm and left leg, breathe in and raise both again. Repeat on the right. By doing this exercise, you can strengthen and stabilize your core, spine, and back muscles.

Lower Body Exercise:


  • Squats: Strengthen your lower back and legs by doing squats. First stand with your feet apart, hip or shoulder width apart. Bend the knees and sit down gently, sending the hips back while the torso is straight. Lift your head up and stretch your arms for balance if necessary. When you return to standing, place a little bend in your knees.

  • Forward Lunges: Stand with legs slightly apart. Bend forward and down until the front knee is at a 90-degree angle. Keep your torso straight and engage your core as you step, bend, and return to the starting position.

  • Glute Bridges: Lie on your back, your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Compress your abs and glutes as you lift your hips, drawing a straight line from your knees to your upper back/shoulders. Hold the breath and then slowly return to the floor and repeat.

What is a pregnancy pillow?


Most of you might wonder, is it just like a normal pillow.!


No, it is a specially designed and contoured pillow that helps support the changing curves and contours of the body. With this, pregnant women can get the best support at different sleeping positions. As months pass by, the body shape of a pregnant woman changes. Most of the traditional pillows are not suitable to embrace the contours of the pregnant women’s body.   • Wedge: This pillow supports a specific area under your abdomen, behind your back, or between your knees. It helps in preventing tumbling during sleep.


Benefits of using a pregnancy pillow:


  • You will be at ease as you adjust to the new sleeping position.

Finally, it is the moment that you have been happily anticipating for months. Meanwhile, you have to get ready to do your best for safe delivery. Labor pain is the indication that your baby is all set to come out to this world. However, the signs of labor pain differ from one woman to another. There is no way to predict how a woman's labor will progress or for how long it will last. Here are a few common signs of labor pain:


Vaginal Discharge:


        As the time gets nearer for the baby to come out of the womb, the mother may experience vaginal discharge which can be pink, brown, or slightly bloody. It is due to the release of a mucus plug that blocks the cervix during pregnancy. However, the mucus plug loosens during childbirth when the cervix begins to enlarge or open.


Water break:


        Water break is considered a positive sign of labor pain. The growth and development of the baby take place in the woman's womb filled with amniotic fluid. When the sac breaks open, the fluid inside surges in some women but flows more slowly in others.
Mothers are advised to visit the gynecologist right after the water bursts. Once the sac breaks the baby is no longer surrounded by the protective fluid and there is a risk of infection.


Periodic contractions/Uterine Contraction


        Periodic contractions happen almost at the end of the pregnancy period. Due to the uterine contractions, the baby moves to a lower position in the birth canal, and eventually, the contractions help push the baby to come out of the womb. Oxytocin is released from the pituitary which stimulates the uterine contraction where the uterus hardens and relaxes alternately. As labor progresses so does the intensity and duration of uterine contractions also increases.

Have you ever wondered how your baby is developing inside your womb.! Let us see here, the different stages that count in during the process of fetal development:


The first stage is fertilization, where the sperm fertilizes the egg and completes the genetic makeup of the human fetus. The gender and genetic development of the fetus begin during the conception period. After about 3 days, the fertilized egg divides rapidly and then enters the uterus through the fallopian tubes and is attached to the uterine wall. The attachment site nourishes the rapidly developing fetus and becomes the placenta.


1st Trimester (1 - 12 weeks) :


4 weeks: After 4 weeks, the embryo's basic structure begins to develop into separate areas forming the head, chest, abdomen, and the organs within.


8 weeks: At this period, the fetus is about 1.1cm long. The facial features such as ears, eyelids, and the tip of the nose develop. The limb buds develop into arms and legs, while the fingers and toes are still in the developing stage.


12 weeks: At this period, the fetus is about 4.4cm long and it begins to move on its own. The fingers and toes can be identified at this stage.


2nd Trimester (13 - 28 weeks) :


16 weeks: At this period, the fetus will be about 4.5cm long. The mother may start to perceive the baby’s movements. Facial features like nose, mouth, chin, and ears are distinguishable, while the fingers and toes are completely developed. The skin on the fingers and toes also has fingerprints. The woman can feel the uterus about 3 inches below her belly button.


20 weeks: At this stage, the baby will be 13.2cm long and weigh about 300gms. At this stage of fetal development, babies can move their facial muscles, yawn, and suck their thumbs.


24 weeks: At this stage, the baby weighs around 680 grams and will be able to respond to sounds. A baby's inner ear canal develops at 24 weeks.


28 weeks: At this stage, the baby weighs more than 1kg and the baby's eyelids open partially and eyelashes have formed. At this stage, the central nervous system can direct rhythmic breathing movements and control body temperature.


3rd Trimester (29 - 40 weeks):


During the third semester, the baby's bones develop. By week 29, the baby starts to make movements like stretching. At this stage, the mother can clearly feel the kicks and movements of the baby. The baby can now widely open its eyes. By week 30, the baby is about 15.7 inches long and weighs about more than 1.3kgs. By week 31, the baby starts to gain weight quickly. Around the 36th week, your baby has grown bigger and the space to move around in the womb is less but still, the mother can feel the stretches.


Around the 39th week, your baby is considered full-term. And as you get nearer to the due date, your baby may turn into a head-down position. The average weight of a baby during birth will be around 2.5kg to 3kg.

Get adequate rest and sleep:

Clean the skin regularly:


Baby's skin is usually coated with a white layer of waxy matter which falls off in the first few weeks after birth. It is a common and natural process so you don’t have to use any kind of creams to rub the skin off. During the first few weeks after birth, clean your baby’s skin using a sponge and warm water and also pay special attention to the baby's mouth and diaper area.


Follow best bathing practices:
