It contains ingredients that can protect your baby from infection and has long-term health benefits for both the baby and the mother; reducing the chances of your baby having severe eczema, obesity, diabetes and breast cancer, ovarian cancer, and diabetes in the breastfeeding mother.


Babies born before 34 to 36 weeks are too small to be able to directly breastfeed, for such babies consider expressing breast milk, and then feed the baby through the tube or save for later.


Breast milk supplement:


Premature babies need more energy and may have different nutritional needs than term babies. In addition to breast milk, they may require;


  • Additional vitamins, minerals, and proteins
  • Formula milk
  • Donor expressed milk.
  • Additional nutrients through the duct into the vein


Formula milk for premature babies:


The neonatal experts will advise you on the best preterm formula along with the quantity, and when it has to be replaced. It depends on how early your baby is born and how much it weighs. Premature formula milk contains additional nutrients to offset the additional demand. It is first given with the help of a tube through the nose or mouth, but then through a bottle, after the baby is able to suck and swallow. Tube feeding for premature babies:


Most of the babies born before 35 weeks should be fed using this method. If premature babies cannot feed on the breast or bottle, they are fed through a tube. The tube passes through the nose and carries food to the baby's stomach. The diet can include expressed breast milk, fortified breast milk, or formula milk.


Total parenteral nutrition:


All the nutrition a child needs is delivered to the vein through the duct, sometimes through the umbilical cord. Total parenteral nutrition is used when the baby's guts are not developed enough to deal with the food that passes through them, or if the baby is too ill or has an intestinal condition. Once the baby's intestines are developed or settled, tube feeding can gradually change the TPN.

imageTitle: STD(Sexually Transmitted Diseases) - Causes, Symptoms & Treatment
content:
STD! A serious condition that can develop or transmit from one person to another through unprotected sexual contact. Well, this does not mean that sexual contact is the only way through which STDs are transmitted. There are many other factors through which a person can develop STD. However, the symptoms vary for men and women.


Some sexually transmitted infections include:


  • Genital herpes.
  • HIV/AIDS
  • Genital warts
  • Hepatitis B
  • Chlamydia
  • Syphilis
  • Gonorrhea
  • Vaginitis
  • Trichomoniasis


Symptoms of STD’s in Men and Women are as follows:


There is a possibility of getting an STD without developing any symptoms. While some sexually transmitted diseases cause noticeable symptoms such as;


Men:


  • Pain or discomfort during intercourse or urination.
  • Sores, bumps, or rashes around the penis, testicles, anus, buttocks, thighs, or mouth.
  • Unusual discharge or bleeding from the penis.
  • Painful or swollen testicles.


Women:


  • Pain or discomfort during intercourse or urination.
  • Sores, bumps, or rashes around the vagina, anus, buttocks, thighs, or mouth.
  • Unusual discharge or bleeding from the vagina.
  • Itching in or around the vagina.


Treatments for STD:  


The treatment for STDs varies depending upon the disease a person has. It is always recommended to get the right treatment at the right time for STDs before resuming any sexual activity.


  • Bacterial sexually transmitted disease:   In general, antibiotics can easily treat bacterial infections. It is important to complete the course, but if you feel better than before then visit your doctor and ask for advice on whether to continue or stop taking the antibiotics.


  • Viral sexually transmitted diseases:  Viral sexually transmitted diseases cannot be treated with antibiotics. Most viral infections have no cure, some can resolve on their own. There are treatment options available to alleviate symptoms and reduce the risk of transmission.


  • Other sexually transmitted diseases Some sexually transmitted diseases are not caused by viruses or bacteria. Instead, they are caused by other small organisms such as;

    • Pubic lice
    • Trichomoniasis
    • Scabies


STD is contagious, that’s why it is important to see a healthcare provider and get the right treatment right away.


Pregnancy & STD:


Sexually transmitted diseases can get transmitted to the baby during pregnancy. In babies, sexually transmitted diseases can cause complications while in some cases they can be life-threatening.


To help prevent STDs in babies, pregnant women need to get tested and treated for possible STDs. If you are positive for one or more STDs during pregnancy, your doctor may prescribe antibiotics, antiviral medications, or other treatments.

Menopause…! It occurs when a woman does not have menstrual cycles for 12 consecutive months and is no longer able to conceive naturally. For most women, menopause begins in the late 40s or early 50s and usually lasts a few years. It can cause unpleasant symptoms, such as hot flashes, weight gain, and so on. Some women get medical help while others turn to natural supplements and remedies to deal with menopause symptoms.


Some natural ways to ease menopause symptoms:


Intake of foods rich in Calcium and Vitamin D:


Consume foods rich in Vitamin D and Calcium. Vitamin D helps you maintain bone density and prevents osteoporosis. It also plays an important role in reducing inflammation and reducing hot flashes. Rich dietary sources such as oily fish, eggs, cod liver oil are rich in vitamin D. Calcium can help you reduce the rate of menopausal bone loss, especially 5 or more years after menopause. Foods such as collard greens, tofu, beans, and spinach are rich in calcium, including dairy products such as yogurt, milk, and cheese.


Achieve and maintain a healthy weight:


Most women might notice weight gain and it is common during menopause. Weight gain can be due to hormonal change, aging, lifestyle, and genetics. However, excess body fat may lead to an increase in developing heart disease and diabetes. It is recommended to avoid the intake of junk food, maintain a healthy diet and make sure to keep your weight in check.


Fruits and vegetables:


Including fruits and vegetables in your diet can help prevent many of the menopause symptoms as they have fewer calories and can help you stay full, and in a way, they are great for maintaining a healthy weight.


Exercise regularly:  


Regular exercise can help you with the symptoms like poor sleep, anxiety, low mood, and fatigue. It also protects against weight gain and various diseases and conditions. However, with regular exercise, there are other health benefits such as improved strength and metabolism, healthier joints and bones. Make sure to exercise for at least 30 - 40 minutes a day.


Protein-rich diet:


Eating protein regularly throughout the day can help prevent the loss of lean muscle mass that comes with age. Intake of protein throughout the day at every meal can slow the loss of muscle mass caused by aging. In addition, high-protein diets can aid in weight loss because they increase fullness and caloric intake. Some foods rich in protein are meat, fish, eggs, legumes, nuts, and dairy products.


Drink enough water:


During menopause, women usually experience dehydration. This is probably due to the decrease in estrogen levels. Drink at least 7 - 15 glasses of water every day. It also reduces bloating with hormonal changes and boosts your metabolism.

Pregnancy brings lots of joy and glows to a woman's life. A pregnant woman experiences various emotional and physical changes. They might also experience changes in their skin like rosy cheeks, and shiny hair while some have breakouts, dark skin patches, acne, and skin tags. Well, these changes are totally natural and common due to changes in hormonal levels. However, if you are worried about the physical changes/beauty, here are some tips to take care of your skin during and post-pregnancy:



Skincare tips to follow during pregnancy:


Moisturize:


During pregnancy, your skin starts to stretch, this stretch can cause itching. Soothe your skin with moisturizer, make sure that the moisturizer contains natural ingredients so that your skin stays hydrated and fresh.


Hydrate:


Moisturizing and Hydrating…!
Well, most of you think that they are the same things, but they are two different things when it comes to skincare. Moisturizer locks the moisture better in your skin whereas hydration increases the water content of your skin. The practice of moisturizing and hydrating results in a good pregnancy skincare routine.


Exfoliate:


Get rid of dull and dead skin and pores, by exfoliating. It not only removes dead skin and pores but also promotes healthy skin. After exfoliation, apply the moisturizer and hydrate new skin cells for better results.


Prevent stretch marks:  


Stretch Marks are a part of the pregnancy journey. These stretch marks leave discoloration and fine lines as your skin stretches to accommodate the baby in the womb. Start using anti-stretch mark creams before and even after pregnancy. Make sure to apply stretch mark cream and massage on certain areas like the stomach and hips for at least two months after childbirth.



Skincare tips to follow post-childbirth:


Black spots:


The stress of motherhood leaves adverse effects on facial skin, leading to the formation of brown spots. To prevent these dark spots from increasing, cleanse the skin twice a day with a mild and gentle cleanser.


Melasma:


During pregnancy, some women notice dark spots developing on their faces. These are called Melasma. This happens due to the high levels of pregnancy hormones affecting pigmentation. These hormones gradually decrease post-delivery. Some brown spots may be less obvious, others may remain forever. For pregnant women with this condition, make sure to avoid constant sun exposure.


Dark circles and puffy eyes:


You may get dark circles and puffy eyes due to hormonal changes or might be due to lack of sleep after childbirth. Your body experiences fatigue because of constantly waking up to feed the baby. Use eye cream containing natural ingredients, and make sure to get enough sleep.


Hypersensitivity and Acne:


Most women after childbirth experience sensitive skin. Anything can cause your skin to react adversely, while sometimes your skin can feel irritated from things like bleach and detergent. Acne! Most common thing experienced by women during pregnancy. High progesterone levels after pregnancy can cause breakouts. Include healthy foods in your diet.


Some of the above skin problems may vanish over time, but some conditions can persist even after delivery and require medical attention. excerpt: Across the globe, about 5.2% of all cancers can be attributed to HPV infection. content:
Across the globe, about 5.2% of all cancers can be attributed to HPV infection. According to the World Health Organization, the frequency of HPV infection is between nine and thirteen percent. HPV is a viral infection that generally causes the growth of warts on the skin. There are around 100+ forms of human papillomavirus, out of which few forms of HPV infection cause warts while others cause different types of cancer.


Still, most HPV infections do not cause cancer. While some types of HPV infection can cause cancer in the anus, penis, vagina, vulva, and back of the throat (oropharyngeal). The infections are transmitted sexually or through skin-to-skin contact.


Cervical cancer ranks as the 2nd most frequent cancer among women in India and also the 2nd most frequent cancer among women between the age of 15 and 45. According to the survey, every year 1 lakh plus women are diagnosed with cervical cancer, and about 10,000+ women die because of cervical cancer.


Effect of HPV on Women during Pregnancy:


Commonly, HPV infection doesn’t cause any noticeable symptoms or severe health problems. In fact, in 9 out of 10 cases, HPV infection goes away on its own within two years. When the virus doesn’t go away on its own, it leads to serious health problems such as genital warts and warts in the throat, cervical cancer, and other cancers.


A positive HPV pregnant woman can pass the infection to the newborn during childbirth. Even if babies do get infected with the HPV virus, their bodies usually clear the virus on their own.


A pregnant woman suffers from large genital warts, leading to blockage in the birth canal. Well, a baby born to a woman with genital warts does not have HPV-related complications. In very rare cases, a baby might develop warts in the throat.


HPV infection causes premature birth and early pregnancy loss. However, if the mother is suffering from the HPV virus that has caused cervical cancer, the baby can be delivered safely.


How can you get HPV?


Anyone in sexual contact is at risk of developing an HPV infection. Some factors that contribute to an increased risk of HPV infection are as follows:


  • Increased number of sexual partners

  • Unprotected vaginal, oral, or anal sex

  • A weakened immune system

  • Having a sexual partner who has HPV


If you get in contact with a high-risk type of HPV, the following factors can make it more likely that the infection will continue and may develop into cancer:


  • Weak immune system

  • Gonorrhea, chlamydia, and herpes simplex

  • Chronic inflammation

  • Receiving anal sex (anal cancer)

  • Using tobacco products (mouth or throat cancer)

  • Having many children (cervical cancer)


HPV Vaccination:


Well, we all know that early protection works best. The HPV vaccine is the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones. The HPV vaccine can be given to children starting at the age of 9. It is most effective when given at ages 11–12. The HPV vaccine is most effective if it's given before HPV exposure.


Children of age 9 to 14 can get the vaccine in a series of two shots over 6 months. Children of age of 15 or above can get the vaccine as a three-dose series, where the 2nd dose is given 1 to 2 months after the 1st dose and the 3rd dose is given 6 months after the 1st dose. It is advised to get all the shots in a series for the vaccine to work effectively. It's also recommended for those between the age 15 to 26 years, who didn't get the vaccine when they were younger. Women who are 30+ can get the HPV vaccine after consulting the gynecologist. It is advised to get regular screenings to help diagnose HPV-related health problems early. This can enhance the outlook and increase the chances of survival. Girls and women should see their gynecologist regularly and get pap smears as recommended, starting at age 21. Be sure to get regular health checkups, screenings, and Pap smear tests to prevent HPV.

Pregnancy brings joy, happiness, and also uncountable fears. Being a first-time mom, the entire experience will be new and nail-bitingly unpredictable. Every pregnant woman will have some common fears of losing a baby/miscarriage or the baby’s health. Also, you may worry and pay more attention to whatever you are doing, whether it could be related to meals or any other daily activity. This feeling is totally natural and cannot be handled.


Here are a few things that may scare a to-be-mom the most. But you need to absolutely stop worrying about them.


What if I have a miscarriage?


Well, if you have a fear of having a miscarriage, then it’s important for you to know what causes miscarriage. It is because of abnormal chromosomes, affecting the development of babies before birth. So miscarriage does not happen because of what you do or not. But you can prevent it by avoiding smoking, alcohol and also making sure to decrease the intake of caffeine.


Most pregnancy outcomes are a healthy baby and a healthy mom. But also less than 20% of pregnancy cases result in miscarriages. Around 6 to 8 weeks of pregnancy, the risk of miscarriage is about 5%.

imageTitle: Childhood Obesity and Diabetes
content:
Noncommunicable diseases..! These are the biggest challenges of this century and childhood obesity is an important part of this. Every parent is worried about every small thing when it comes to their child’s health. The prevalence of obesity among 5-19-year-old Indian children ranges between 3.6 – 11.7% and by 2025 there will be 17 million obese children in India.


Obesity has led to a dramatic increase in Type-2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in children and adolescents. It not only affects the physical well-being of children but also their mental health. Unfortunately, this problem is increasing and according to a study, the percentage of obese children has tripled since 1970.


What is Obesity?


Obesity means the presence of an excess amount of fat in the body. It occurs due to the consumption of an excessive amount of calories that the body can use.


Body Mass Index > 85th percentile for age and sex is considered overweight and >95th percentile is diagnosed as obesity.


OBESITY leading to Type 2 DIABETES MELLITUS!


Obesity promotes insulin resistance, which in turn leads to T2DM.


Nowadays, young children are getting type 2 diabetes, which is also known as adult-onset diabetes. Type 2 Diabetes in children is a long-term disease. Without treatment, the disorder can lead to serious long-term consequences. Children are prone to get Type 2 diabetes because of obesity problems.


T2DM is often asymptomatic. Genetic and environmental risk factors such as maternal obesity, gestational diabetes, and lack of physical activity should be identified. Major risk factors for T2DM include overweight and obesity, signs of insulin resistance including acanthosis nigricans, hypertension, impaired lipids, and polycystic ovary syndrome.


T2DM has long term complications like


  • Progressive neuropathy

  • Retinopathy leading to blindness

  • Nephropathy leading to chronic renal failure

  • Cardiovascular disease leading to stroke

  • Myocardial infarction

  • Sudden death


PREVENTION IS ALWAYS BETTER THAN CURE!


Weight loss and/or prevention of weight gain is the best way to prevent T2DM among children with risk factors for the disease.


Reversing obesity through lifestyle changes plays a major role,


Simple steps to prevent T2DM:


  • Avoid consumption of calorie-dense, nutrition-poor foods such as sugar-sweetened beverages, fast foods, high-fat or high-sodium processed foods, and calorie-dense snacks.

  • Retinopathy leading to blindness

  • Increase the intake of dietary fiber, fruits, and vegetables.

  • Follow timely, regular meals, and avoid constant “grazing” during the day, especially after school and after supper.

  • Encourage the consumption of whole fruits rather than fruit juices.

  • Make your child get engaged in at least 20 minutes, optimally 60 minutes, of vigorous physical activity at least 5 days per week

  • Limit the nonacademic screen time to 1 to 2 hours per day

  • Foster healthy sleep patterns in children and adolescents to decrease the likelihood of developing obesity due to changes in caloric intake and metabolism related to disordered sleep.


A healthy diet and a healthy lifestyle can help prevent obesity and diabetes in children. If your child is already having diabetes, then make sure your child eats healthy and follows a healthy lifestyle so that the risk of complications is reduced. Opt for Pharmacotherapy with specific medication only when lifestyle modification has failed.


Parents! If you notice any of the severe signs or symptoms of obesity and diabetes in your child, immediately consult a paediatric endocrinologist. Also, make a visit to the hospital at least once a year for a full body checkup. Make sure to note and focus on your child’s height and weight frequently. content:
With 80% of the adult population getting COVID-19 vaccinated, attention has shifted toward how to vaccinate teens. The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) are now recommending the COVID-19 vaccine for teenagers between the age of 15 and 18 years.


The disease can spread if the teens are asymptomatic. Additionally, although teens might get mild symptoms when exposed to COVID-19, there are still many cases of acute lung infection and hospitalization. And although teens are less likely to be diagnosed with serious illness early on, they are more susceptible to chronic COVID symptoms after early recovery from the disease.


Benefits of the Covid-19 vaccine for teens are:


  • COVID-19 protection: The primary goal of the COVID-19 vaccine in teens, is to protect them against the virus by improving their immunity. Vaccination for teens between the ages of 15 and 18 is the first step to avoid being infected by COVID-19.

  • Reduces disease severity: As seen in adults, the COVID-19 vaccine reduces the severity of the disease in the event of a COVID-19 infection. Although the incidence of disease in teens is significantly less than that of adults, there have been cases of serious infection in teens.

  • Achieve herd immunity: Researchers believe that India has herd immunity when more populations have antibodies to COVID-19. Immunization of the herd occurs through immunization acquired through infection and vaccination (hybrid immunity). Because a small percentage of teenagers suffer from the disease, vaccination can help herd immunity.

  • Improve Social Work: They have been confined to homes because schools, colleges are closed. This had a significant impact on mental health and social well-being. Vaccinated teens can go to school with less risk. International travel is another consideration for tourism and educational purposes.


Do teens get the same side effects as adults with the COVID vaccine?


Teens with the COVID-19 vaccine may receive the same side effects as adults. The most common side effects are - pain in the arms, redness, and swelling in the area where the vaccine is given.


Teens may have the following within one or two days of receiving the vaccine:


  • Tiredness

  • Headache

  • Pain or sore muscles

  • Cold

  • Nausea

  • Fever


Consult your doctor on how to handle vaccine side effects and when to call for problems. Usually, these side-effects resolve on their own within 48 hours. Don't delay, visit your doctor and get vaccinated as soon as possible.

Exercise..! It is one of the best ways to improve mental and physical well-being during and after pregnancy. The best thing you can do for yourself and your baby is to stay healthy and fit Even if you have morning sickness or other discomforts in your early pregnancy, then getting up and moving often will help you feel better.


With regular exercise, you can regulate your weight, prepare yourself to handle more weight, and get in shape for childbirth. It is also good for mood and sleep.


You probably aren't noticing many major body changes yet, apart from the feeling that you need to rest a bit more. The most important rules for first-trimester exercise are to pay attention to these new energy limits and avoid falls. Make sure your doctor knows what exercise you are doing, and talk to your doctor before you start with anything.


Let’s have a look at some of the exercises, which are safe to do, during the first trimester;


  • Pilates: It can help you improve core strength and balance, reducing the risk of falls. It can also help relieve back pain associated with weight gain, especially in the front of the body. Pregnant women who are used to Pilates can often follow their usual routine during the first trimester. But, before you start with your second phase, consult your doctor first.


  • Yoga: Yoga allows you to gently stretch and strengthen your body. It also encourages mindfulness skills such as controlled breathing and meditation, which can be very helpful during labor. If you already practice yoga and your pre-pregnancy routine is comfortable in your new condition, then keep it up. And any amount of yoga is healthy, as long as you don't overexert yourself by pulling muscles or overheating. Performing yoga half an hour a day is great.


Exercises that you should avoid:


  • Back curves

  • Poses that distort the abdomen

  • Any position in which the feet are above the head, such as handstands

  • Walk: Walking is one of the simplest exercises to do during pregnancy. An easy walk gets you moving and strengthens your upper body by swinging your arms. Get your heart racing by picking up the pace. If you don't have the practice of walking, then start with 10 minutes a day, 3 to 5 times a week. Work up to 30 minutes a day. To help prevent falls, stay away from broken sidewalks or rocky paths.

  • Spinning courses or pedaling with a stationary bike: Off-road biking, like mountain biking, is not a good option for pregnant people due to the risk of falls and injuries. Stationary bikes, spin classes, and safe flat bike lanes are alternatives with significantly lower risks.

imageTitle: How to ensure a healthy diet for your infant
content:
Parenthood is the most beautiful phase in a couple’s life.
When it’s your first time, parenthood can be very exciting to watch your children grow, develop, and interact. children usually grow faster after 1 year and they need healthy and nutritious food every day. It is important to help them develop a strong body and intelligent mind.


The first few years of your baby's life are very important. During these years, the health and nutrition of the baby lay the foundations for a healthy life. While all of their developmental years are equally important, particularly the first year is significant. A proper healthy diet for your baby in the first 12 months will affect the growth and well-being in the following years. As a new parent, it's easy to get overwhelmed and cared for. But if you remember a few basics, there's no reason to worry.


How often do you need to breastfeed your baby?



The baby who is not breastfed should be fed often. By the time the baby is 1 year old, he is trying to crawl, walk and learn other activities. Therefore, their diet schedule should be four to five times a day to give them extra energy and nutrition


What should you feed your child for healthy growth?


The baby should be fed keeping in mind its ability to digest. It can be semi-solid, including fruit or vegetable puree (baked potatoes, carrots, etc.). Generally, packaged baby foods available in the market are not as nutritious as they seem.
When a child develops teeth, he or she can eat everything the family eats, but it must be filled with extra nourishment. While the taste of food may surprise the baby, it's best to give it time to get used to the semi-solid baby food. Be patient for an easy transition from liquid to semi-solid.


How to find out if your baby is full or hungry?


It is very common to think that crying is one of the signs that your child might be hungry. There are several reasons behind babies crying: they must be tired, have abdominal pain, need a diaper change, etc. Some other common signs that help mothers recognize that their baby is hungry are smacking the lips, leaning toward the chest or milk bottle, placing their hands in their mouths, or sucking the fingers. Similarly, infants show visible signs when they are full or do not want to eat. For example, pushing a milk bottle or spoon away is a clear sign of full emotion. In addition, when the baby is satisfied with hunger, it sleeps easily or actively moves. These signs help the caregiver not to force the baby to eat too much.


What to do when your baby refuses to eat?


By age 1, the baby needs solid food. Make sure they are hungry at lunch, only then will they be able to eat properly. In the first few days, when the baby begins to eat solid food, try some experiments to understand the baby's reaction to food and identify its favorite meal. It helps to create unique combinations of foods that your child likes and refuses to eat. Be calm and patient if your child refuses to eat anything special. Avoid junk foods.

Spend time with your partner:



You probably already know that a couple-time will move way down the list once the baby is born. Instead of complaining about this, take advantage of the time you have now, not sadly or wistfully, but deliberately. Be intentional about saving some fun and romantic memories that you can savor later. What you do is less important than the time you spend together.


Focus on - who will do what:


The idea here is to avoid some of the typical hard feelings that can arise between new parents by discussing those details ahead of time, without making assumptions. Discuss if your partner plans to exclusively breastfeed or if she will handle some bottle feedings. Talk about sleep i.e will you sleep with the baby, will you share the nightly chores, housework, cooking, and other chores.


Read some books about soon-to-be parents:


Explore the parenting shelf at the library or bookstore and ask other first-time to be parents for the titles of the most enlightening or helpful books they've read. Take a look at anything that makes you feel more competent, confident, and less alone.


Handle some practical tasks:


Stay busy and cook as many freezable meals as time allows. Take that baby list and go shopping, making sure that you have enough supplies for the first few weeks, like small diapers, baby wipes, and enough crib onesies and sheets. If you're taking a break from work, prepare lists and instructions for whoever is filling them out.


Talk to other parents:


Think about the parents you are closest to. Whether it's your parents or siblings or your best friend, find one or two new or veteran parents you can count on to be truly honest. Avoid people who will tell you everything is horrible as you would not wish for negativity around you.

Pelvic pain is not something to worry about during pregnancy. Be reassured that many expecting mothers feel pain in the pelvic area during pregnancy. Sometimes it’s the cravings, nausea, morning sickness, mood swings, and one of such experiences that most expecting mothers have during pregnancy is pelvic pain. However, there are many ways to feel at ease or make this discomfort more bearable.


After all, ligaments stretch, changes in hormonal level, and organs shift a little around to make room for your little one to grow. But sometimes excess pain indicates that there is something wrong.

There are several common and less serious causes of pelvic pain during pregnancy. Most often, pelvic pain is caused when your body is making room to help your baby pass through your pelvis during delivery.

Common causes of pelvic pain during pregnancy are as follows:

  • Growth spurts of the fetus and uterus.

  • Symphysis pubis dysfunction, it’s inflammation and pain caused by the movement of joints during and after pregnancy.

  • Pressure and stress on your body.

  • Secretion of the hormone called relaxin results in the softening of ligaments. This hormone helps in loosening the joints and ligaments to prepare your pelvis for delivery.


Some common symptoms of having pelvic pain are:


  • Pain over the pubic bone at the front in the center, roughly level with your hips and below your tummy.

  • Pain across your lower back

  • Pain around the area between your vagina and anus

  • Pain while spreading your thighs


Here are some ways to cope with Pelvic pain:


  • Stay active and avoid activities that might make the pain worse.

  • Involve your spouse, family, and friends in daily activities for help.

  • Rest and relax often.

  • Consider alternative sleeping positions such as lying on your side with pillows between your legs for maximum comfort.

  • Sit in a sturdy chair with the help of a rolled-up towel or pillow to support your lower back.

  • Do not engage in activities involving asymmetrical lumbar positions.

  • Sit cross-legged, stretch, push or pull to one side, and bend and turn to lift or carry something on your side.


When to call your gynecologist?


If you feel the pain is getting worse or something is wrong, don't hesitate to call your gynecologist. If you notice any of these following signs, visit your gynecologist immediately;

  • Pelvic pain that makes it harder to walk or speak

  • More than four contractions in one hour for two hours

  • Watery, green, or bloody secretions from the vagina

title: Important Factors that Influence Child Development

imageTitle: Important Factors that Influence Child Development
content:
From the moment your child is born, as a parent, you are amazed at every look. You start recording every milestone from their first laugh to their first step to their first little wave. And as you watch them grow from tiny sleepless babies to toddlers and beyond with your sleep-deprived eyes, you are reminded every day of how fascinating creatures they are and how quickly these little humans have learned.


You see them grow and develop every day. Although the terms growth and development are used synonymously, they have different meanings. Growth refers to incremental changes in physical attributes such as height, weight, size, etc., while development refers to qualitative changes in growth that lead to maturity. Growth and development contribute to each other and are inseparable.


Factors that influence the growth and development of a child are as follows;


  • Heredity: It is the transmission of physical characteristics from parents to children through their genes. It influences all aspects of physical appearance such as height, weight, eye color, hair texture, intelligence, and aptitude. Diseases and conditions, such as heart disease, diabetes, obesity, can be transmitted through genes, which adversely affect the growth and development of the child. However, environmental factors and nutrition can bring about the best of genes.


  • Environment: It plays a crucial role in the development of children and it represents the total amount of physical and mental stimulation a child receives. Some of the environmental factors that influence early childhood development include the physical, environmental and geographic location of the child's home, as well as the social environment and relationships with family and friends. It is easy to understand that a well-fed child performs better than a deprived child; The ever-present environment of children contributes to this. A good school and a loving family build strong social and interpersonal skills in children, which allows them to excel in other areas such as academic and extracurricular activities. This is, of course, different for children who are raised in a stressful environment.


  • Sexuality: Another important factor affecting the physical development and mental development of a child is gender. Boys and girls grow up differently, especially as they approach puberty. Boys are taller and physically stronger than girls. However, girls mature faster in adolescence, while boys mature later. The physical structure of their bodies has variations that make the boys more athletic and suitable for activities that require physical toughness. Their instincts also change, so they become interested in different things.


  • Exercise and Health: The word exercise here does not mean physical exercise as a discipline nor does it mean that children should be intentionally engaged in physical activities to help them grow. The exercise here refers to regular playtime and sports activities, which help the body build muscle and increase bone mass. Proper exercise helps children grow well and reach milestones in time or quickly. Exercise helps to keep them healthy and fight diseases by strengthening immunity, especially if they are playing outside. This is because outdoor play exposes them to microbes that help build resistance and prevent allergies.


  • Hormones: Hormones belong to the endocrine system and affect various functions of our body. They are produced by various glands located in specific parts of the body to secrete hormones that regulate body functions. Their timely functioning is crucial to the normal physical and mental development of children. An imbalance in the functioning of the hormone-secreting glands can lead to developmental disorders, obesity, behavioral problems, and other diseases. During puberty, gonads produce sex hormones that regulate the development of sexual organs and the appearance of secondary sexual characteristics in boys and girls.


  • Nutrition: Nutrition is a crucial factor in growth because everything that the body needs to build and heal comes from the food we eat. Malnutrition can lead to deficiency diseases that adversely affect the growth and development of children. On the other hand, overeating can lead to obesity and health problems such as diabetes and heart disease in the long run. A balanced diet rich in vitamins, minerals, proteins, carbohydrates, and fats is essential for brain and body development.

imageTitle: All you need to know about NICU
content:
Every year 78 out of every 1,000 babies born remain in the NICU, where most of them are premature babies.


NICU - Neonatal Intensive Care Unit is an intensive care unit for newborns. It is a high-tech nursery with specialized equipment and highly trained staff who care for preterm and other newborns who need serious medical care. High-tech monitors in most NICUs check important signs, such as your baby's heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen levels. Many have ventilators to help your baby breathe easier and have CT and MRI machines to capture detailed images of your baby's body, including your baby's brain.


Different levels of NICU:


  • Level 1 NICU: As a basic stage of intensive care for newborns, the level I unit is able to revitalize newborns, provide treatment to newborns, stabilize and care for babies born between 35 to 37 gestational weeks. In the latter case, it is usually an interim arrangement until the child is transferred to another facility with the necessary level of care. The ecosystem in the Phase I NICU is usually composed of pediatricians, general practitioners, nurses, and other medical professionals.


  • Level 2 NICU: The level 2 NICU provides all the services of level 1 and additional specialized services. They are composed of pediatricians, neonatologists, neonatal nurses, and all medical specialists who require a level 1 NICU. The level 2 NICUs extend care for babies born premature for up to 32 gestational weeks or weigh up to 1,500 grams. They are suitable for infants with underdeveloped immune systems or moderate to severe diseases and for those who require mechanical ventilation or advanced care after intensive care.


  • Level 3 NICU: It is the next stage of intensive care for newborns after level 2 NICU.
